Local News Home > Local News Tweet My Yahoo Print Wednesday, Nov 02 2011 04:54 PM Sex offender takes plea deal in case that prompted change to state law
BY JASON KOTOWSKI Californian staff writer jkotowski@bakersfield.com
Convicted sex offender German Baeza pleaded no contest Wednesday to forcible sodomy and assault to commit rape in connection with sexually assaulting two teenage girls last year in a case that led to changes in notifying the public when a sex offender skips parole.
Prosecutor Melissa Allen said that Baeza agreed to a stipulated sentence of 30 years in prison. She said she's happy with the plea agreement, especially because the victims won't have to come to court and testify.
Fred Gagliardini, Baeza's attorney, said he advised his client to accept the plea deal because he was facing multiple life terms if convicted at trial. By taking the deal, 27-year-old Baeza could possibly have a couple of decades outside prison after serving his sentence.
Wednesday morning's hearing before Kern County Superior Court Judge Michael G. Bush took only a few minutes, Gagliardini said.
Sentencing is scheduled for Dec. 6.
Baeza cut off his ankle monitor July 5, 2010 and was on the loose two and a half weeks, police reported. The attacks happened during that time, police said.
Deputies said a 15-year-old girl reported being raped by a man, later identified as Baeza, she met on an Internet social networking site. She had agreed to meet him at a local fast-food restaurant, and after dinner he lured her into his vehicle by saying he would drive her to a family member's home.
Instead, he drove her to an orchard east of Bakersfield and raped her, deputies reported.
The other incident, investigated by Bakersfield police, happened in the north alley in the 700 block of Monterey Street, police reported. A 14-year-old girl walking through the alley was confronted by Baeza, who brandished a gun and forced her into a vehicle parked nearby.
Baeza tried to remove her pants, but she fought and managed to escape, police reported.
The California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation notified local law enforcement when Baeza went missing, but the public wasn't notified because Baeza had not been classified as a violent sexual predator. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger issued an executive order in early August 2010 ordering the department to notify the public when a sex offender skips parole.
Baeza pleaded no contest to a rape charge in 2004 and was sentenced to six years in prison, according to the Kern County Superior Court website.
